metadata.title: Emission control strategy by adding alumina and cerium oxide nano particle in biodiesel

sections.text:
M AN
US CR
AC CE
PT ED
In order to evaluate the effect of nano particles such as Alumina (Al2O3) and Cerium oxide (CeO2) as additives in Jatropha biodiesel, an experimental investigation is carried out to study the performance and emission characteristics in a single cylinder, four stroke DI diesel engine. Alumina and Cerium oxide nano particles are added with Jatropha biodiesel at mixed proportions forming 10, 30 and 60 parts per million. Significant improvement in the brake thermal efficiency near to that of neat diesel is observed for the nano particle blended test fuels along with the reduction of nitric oxide, carbon monoxide, unburned hydrocarbon and smoke emission by 13 %, 60 %, 33 % and 32 % respectively.
Keywords: Nano particle, Alumina, Cerium oxide, Nitric oxide, Carbon monoxide.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Biodiesel is considered as the main alternative fuels for compression ignition engines, because of their properties such as rich oxygen content, higher kinematic viscosity, reduced smoke emission and diluted level of pollutants from the engine exhaust (Smoke, Carbon monoxide, particulate matter and unburned hydrocarbons). Biodiesel containing 10 % oxygen content helps in better combustion of the fuel [1]; on the other hand, it results in the formation of high local temperatures inducing more NOx emissions during combustion.

When compared to petrol and diesel, a 12 % hike in NOx emission is observed for biodiesel fuel [2]. To control such NOx emissions many strategies have been followed by researchers around the countries such as biodiesel blends, engine modification, exhaust gas reduction techniques and alteration in fuel formulations. Among them, fuel formulation techniques are considered as the most beneficial way of controlling the level of pollutants at the engine exhaust. In continuation of such techniques, the addition of nano particles in biodiesel results in reducing the level of pollutants at the engine exhaust and enhancing the engine performance substantially. Nano particle blended test fuels show better thermal properties, due to the higher surface area to volume ratio of the nano particle [3], resulting in increased oxidation of hydrocarbons and acting as oxygen buffer against NO [4]. A few experiments were conducted with nano particles as additives in both diesel and biodiesel fuels with significant reduction of exhaust emission and improved brake specific fuel consumption. An experimental investigation with cerium oxide nano particle as addition (at 20, 40 and 60 ppm (parts per million)) in Jatropha biodiesel fuel had shown significant NO reduction by 30 % and hydrocarbon emissions by 40 %, besides increased brake thermal efficiency by 1.5 % [4]. Experimental investigation conducted in a single-cylinder four stroke direct injection variable compression ratio diesel engine using diesel-biodiesel-ethanol blends blended with cerium oxide nanoparticle at 25 ppm, resulted in drastic reduction of exhaust emissions such as hydrocarbon, nitric oxide and carbon monoxide [5]. The addition of aluminium nano particle in diesel along with 3–6 % volume of water addition as fuel in a diesel engine shows reduced concentration of smoke and nitrous oxide with significant improvement in brake thermal efficiency [6]. Basha and anand, [7] drew attention of blending two nano particles namely alumina and CNT (dosing ratio of 25 and 50 ppm) in Jatropha biodiesel and found maximum reduction of NO by 23 % for alumina and CNT blended Jatropha biodiesel. In continuation

with significant NO reduction, the brake thermal efficiency of engine increases for alumina and cerium oxide blended Jatropha biodiesel along with smoke opacity reduction by 1.5 %.
From the literatures, the blending of two nano particles in biodiesel shows the most promising results for the performance and emission characteristics of the engine in particular NO emission compared to the individual addition of a nano particle. So, in this present experimental investigation, two nano particles are blended in various parts per million (ppm) with Jatropha biodiesel and the performance and emission characteristics of the test fuels are investigated in comparison with neat diesel and neat biodiesel as base fuels.

sections.heading: Nano particle Characterisation & Test Fuels
sections.text:
Alumina and Cerium oxide nano particles are procured from Alfa Aesar and Sigma Aldrich Company respectively and its specifications are given in Table 1. The morphology of the alumina and cerium oxide nano particles are determined by Scanning Electron Microscope (Model: VEGA3 TESCAN, Czech Republic) as shown in Fig. 1 & 2 respectively and the crystalline phase of nanoparticles are determined by X-ray Diffraction (Model: Rigaku, Ultima IV, Japan) and the intensities are compared with the data from the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS) as shown in Fig. 3 & 4 respectively. Three types of test fuels are prepared by equally dispersing Al2O3 and CeO2 nano particles in mass fraction forming 10, 30 and 60 ppm with Jatropha biodiesel. To prepare the JBD5A5C test fuel, nano particles Al2O3 and CeO2 of 5 ppm each, are added to the Jatropha biodiesel and dispersed using an apparatus called Ultrasonicator. An Ultrasonicator is used for equally dispersing Al2O3 and CeO2 nano particles in Jatropha biodiesel for nearly 1–2 hours before the start of the experiment. The stability characteristic tests are carried out for the test fuels in graduated test tubes and found stable for 2 days. The same procedure is carried out for the preparation

of other test fuels JBD15A15C and JBD30A30C respectively and the properties of the test fuels are shown in Table 2. Engine setup Fig. 5 shows the schematic view of the experimental setup and Table 3 shows the engine specification utilized for the present study. The experimental setup consists of a single cylinder, four-stroke air cooled diesel engine running at a constant speed of 1500 rpm with a rated power of 4.4 kW. Before and after the engine being run by the test fuel, the engine is allowed to run on neat diesel in order to ensure the consumption of test fuels in the fuel injection system is fully purged. The exhaust gases namely nitric oxide (NO), carbon monoxide (CO), unburned hydrocarbons (HC) and smoke from the engine exhaust are measured by using a gas analyzer such as AVL 444 Di-Gas analyzer and AVL 437 Smoke meter respectively. Three trials are accomplished under the steady state conditions and the repeatability of all the results are found to be within 2%. The uncertainties for the measured and absolute values for the parameters such as brake thermal efficiency, NO, Unburned HC, CO and smoke opacity are ± 1.5 %, ± 1 ppm, ± 1 ppm, ± 0.01 vol and ± 1 % respectively.

sections.heading: Performance Characteristics
sections.text:
Fig. 6 illustrates the variations of the brake specific fuel consumption (BSFC) and brake thermal efficiency (BTE) under brake mean effective pressure (bmep). The brake specific fuel consumption of the engine helps in the identification of the fuel economy, where the higher the brake specific fuel consumption reflects in a lower fuel economy and vice versa. Higher brake specific fuel consumption and lower brake thermal efficiency are observed for neat biodiesel (BSFC = 0.318 kg/kWh, BTE = 28.6 %) compared to neat diesel (BSFC = 0.263 kg/kWh, BTE = 32.3 %), due to its lower calorific value and higher density property

The BSFC for the test fuels shows improved brake specific fuel consumption and brake thermal efficiency for the test fuels, such as 0.314 kg/kWh & 29 % for JBD5A5C, 0.303 kg/kWh & 30 % for JBD15A15C, 0.293 kg/kWh & 31 % for JBD30A30C respectively, due to the enhanced surface area to volume ratio of the nano particle favouring better combustion [9].

sections.heading: Emission Characteristics
sections.text:
The major pollutants emitted at the exhaust of the engine are NO, CO, smoke and unburned HC. Among them, the most problematic gas emission is Nitric Oxide (NO). NO is generally formed by reacting nitrogen with hydrocarbon during combustion and also by reacting nitrogen with the oxygen molecule at high temperature [10]. Due to the oxygenated nature of biodiesel, the higher content of the oxygen molecule in biodiesel undergoes a reaction with nitrogen at high temperature inside the combustion chamber resulting in higher NO emission. It can be witnessed with the values of NO emission for neat biodiesel as 1390 ppm and neat diesel as 1320 ppm shown in Fig. 7. With the addition of alumina and cerium oxide nano particles to neat biodiesel, lower NO emissions are observed for the test fuels JBD30A30C, JBD15A15C and JBD5A5C as 1208 ppm, 1249 ppm and 1302 ppm respectively. The maximum percentage reduction of NO observed for the test fuels JBD30A30C, JBD15A15C and JBD5A5C are 13 %, 10 % and 6 % respectively due to the enhanced catalytic activity [3,4] and also by the ability of nano particles to scavenge nitric oxide radical [14]. NO emissions that are produced during combustion of test fuels are reduced to N2 by the following reactions shown below [15, 16].
4 CeO2 → 2 Ce2O3 + O2 Ce2O3 +Al2O3 → 2 CeAlO3 4 CeAlO3 + 2 NO → 4 CeO2 + 2 Al2O3 + N2

The simultaneous reduction of exhaust gas temperature are observed for the test fuels JBD30A30C, JBD15A15C and JBD5A5C as 302 °C, 310 °C and 321°C respectively, when compared with the EGT of neat diesel and neat biodiesel as 325 °C and 339 °C respectively shown in Fig. 7. CO, smoke and unburned HC are formed due to the incomplete combustion of fuel. The CO emission for neat biodiesel is lower than that of neat diesel, due to the oxygen conversion of CO to CO2 [11]. As illustrated in Fig.8, the reduction in CO emission observed for JBD5A5C, JBD15A15C and JBD30A30C test fuels are 0.03 % vol, 0.03 % vol and 0.02 % vol respectively, compared to the neat biodiesel of 0.05 % vol and neat diesel of 0.09 % vol. These reductions of CO emission for the test fuels are due to the ability of nano particles to convert CO to CO2 by its potent redox-active property [17]. Unburned hydrocarbon is mainly formed due to the incomplete combustion of fuel and by sudden burning of unburned mixture present inside the combustion chamber. The unburned mixture between the piston crevices and the cylinder burns suddenly during the combustion process, resulting in partial burning of the mixture by emitting higher unburned hydrocarbon [12]. As illustrated in Fig.8, reduction in unburned hydrocarbon are observed for the test fuels JBD5A5C, JBD15A15C and JBD30A30C as 17, 15 and 12 ppm respectively compared with neat diesel and neat biodiesel of 25 and 18 ppm respectively. Significant reduction in unburned hydrocarbon are observed for the nano particle blended test fuels due to the supply of adequate oxygen by the nano particle for the better combustion [4]. Smoke opacity is the percentage measure of smoke absorption by light [13]. The high oxygen content of neat biodiesel results in better combustion with lower smoke opacity compared to neat diesel. Fig.8 shows good reduction of smoke opacity for the test fuels JBD5A5C, JBD15A15C and JBD30A30C as 33.4 %, 30.2 % and 25.6 % respectively, compared to neat diesel and neat biodiesel as 43.5 % and 37.6 % respectively, where a similar effect is observed in some studies [3,5,7,9].

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
In the present study, the emission and performance characteristics of a diesel engine on the addition of alumina and cerium oxide nano particles in biodiesel are experimentally investigated and the results are discussed below:
For JBD30A30C test fuel, higher brake thermal efficiency of 31 % is observed, which is almost near to the brake thermal efficiency of neat diesel by 32 %. A significant percentage reduction of NO by 13 %, CO by 60 %, Unburned HC by 33 % and smoke emission by 32 % are observed for JBD30A30C test fuel compared to neat biodiesel. Hence, the nano particle addition to neat biodiesel will be a promising technique for increasing the performance and reducing the emission characteristics of the engine, without any engine modifications.

sections.heading: Highlights:
sections.text: Nano particle as additive in fuels is the new modernization fuel formulation technique that helps in the better combustion of fuel. Alumina and Cerium oxide nano particles are used for this study and blended with neat biodiesel. Brake thermal efficiency and brake specific fuel consumption for the test fuels almost near to neat diesel are observed. Drastic reduction of NO, CO, Unburned HC and smoke opacity are observed for nano particle blended test fuels compared to neat biodiesel.
